documents.title: i feel most at home on stage
text: sw71063 asks : you really look like you are having fun when on stage , does making music ever become just a job ?
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 2:08pm i love what i do , i love all the different parts of it - it 's never mundane .
so i love it from writing , through to recording , editing , mixing , mastering , artwork , touring , rehearsals , all of it .
interviews , i do because they 're necessary .
but i never think : yippee , i 've got interviews today !
but i do n't mind doing them .
it 's not creative , and it gets repetitive .
part of the reason i write is so i do n't have to talk about things - and then you find yourself having to talk about things .
and then wondering : what the hell ?
how did that happen ?
; - ) but on stage , it 's probably where i feel most at home , performing .

that 's the reason to make music you want to make - i ca n't imagine how awful it must be to make an album to try and get a hit , hating it , and having to tour it , talk about it , and pretend you like it .
the moral of the story is : always make the music you want to perform , for maybe two or three years .
and maybe all your life !
carlbr0wn asks : what was it like having dylan big you up ?
which of his songs do you love the most ?
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 2:04pm to have my name uttered from his sweet , sweet lips made me die and go to heaven .
i think i 'm going to have that on my gravestone : here lies imelda may , bob dylan liked her .
i ca n't choose between his songs , if i 'm honest - i have books of his lyrics and i get completely immersed in his words .
maybe ballad of a thin man ?
or maybe the times they are a'changing might be a good one for the period we 're living in .
just like a woman is a perfectly rounded song .
he 's just brilliant .
claireybear asks : have you had any negative feedback , particularly from the rockabilly community with your change of look ?
i love both !
does songwriting come easy to you or is it a struggle , and is it lyrics or tune first ?
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:56pm i always knew with this album i was going to lose fans .
and possibly gain some others .
i 'm fine with that .
i 've never made music to please others , and i 'm not going to start now .
i 've been gigging and writing for 26 years , but only known for seven of those , and i started singing blues , jazz , all kinds of roots music .
i 've never been 100 % pure rockabilly and i 've always stated that .
how i got involved with it in the first place was that i mixed it with blues and jazz and punk and gospel , and was told : drop the rockabilly part .
that made me want to do it more , because of the natural rebellious streak in me , and because i could n't understand why such an influential music was so shunned .
without rockabilly , we would never have had punk , rock'n'roll , progressive rock , and most things we love today .
however , i do n't like being tied to anything , i do n't like to feel constricted or made to feel i have to conform to any one idea of me .
i still love the music , but as an artist , as a creative , i must grow , expand , and not get complacent .
and hopefully progress .

more than anything , i want to feel free , i want to have fun , i will always follow my heart , which is how i got into rockabilly in the first place - by not listening to others and doing what i felt was right for me at the time .
and i will continue to learn , grow and enjoy myself regardless of gaining or losing fans .
writing this album , i wanted to make all preconceived notions of me stop .
i felt like i 'd been put in a box with a bow around it .
and possibly did that a little to myself too .
i wanted it all to stop .
i wanted to breathe , and write from a clean slate .
and see what came out of me , rather than decide what album i was going to make .
i dug deep , was very honest , and this album is the result of that .

documents.title: my approach to songwriting
text: 8118hillcrest asks : hello from columbus , indiana , usa .
you 're fantastic !
question : have you taken a break from writing as you promote this album ?
do you have surges of inspiration where you do a lot of writing or do you write when the inspiration hits no matter how busy you are with other things ?
hope to see you in chicago !
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:46pm hi !
i love indiana .
i always have a notebook with me , or a collection of scraps of paper that i randomly write on .
i take inspiration every day from every thing , and i might just write one word , or a chorus , or something .
but i find it difficult to write in the middle of so much crazy promotion ; i do n't feel at my most creative when i 'm on such a crazy schedule .
when i write , i like to take time to let my brain wander .
and i like to write specifically for each album , although i might use some things i 've scribbled down during the course of a year .
when i 'm writing an album i go back to my notepads to get ideas and inspiration from whatever 's in them .
i write bits of songs when i 'm walking ; that lovely moment before you fall asleep .
things people say .
somebody sent me a of a flower this morning , my friend jacques in corsica , and i just replied `` beauty full '' .
i like to toy with words like that .

documents.title: the joy of working with t bone burnett
text: glimmertwin14 asks another : did t bone burnett give you any music to listen to as templates for the album i.e things he had done in the past ?
( my favourite is the peter case , bo deans , elvis costello purple patch on 1986 . )
thanks from nz !
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:42pm absolutely not .
i had the album written by the time i met him , and i 'm very much about not listening to things that might sway you .
and t bone wanted to get my sound on this album , my own sound .
we had many meetings before recording ; i think to create a good relationship , and then we were in a great position to discuss everything .

we went through every track in depth , and he wanted all the references in my brain for each song , whether it be another artist or a time , a movie i have to admit i sometimes reference the sky , or textures .
and t bone and i luckily speak the same language .
he was amazing to work with , and created the perfect vibe .
and i hope i get to work with him again as soon as possible .

references-wise , there 'd be maybe a david lynch movie ; i 'd talk about it wanting to be a dark nightclub at the end of the night when everyone 's gone home , type of vibe ; or i 'd say i 'd want a velvet texture with a shot of whisky .
or a beautiful moon on a cold crisp night .
and t bone would say : yes !
or : i thought that would be an acoustic number ?
and i 'd say , no , i have it in my mind as a kickass rock'n'roll track with bass and fuzz .
and then another we 'd be in complete agreement that a song had to be sultry , and sexy , almost like singing into one body 's ear .
he 's brilliant - he 's a very intelligent , creative man ; very open minded and forward thinking , charismatic individual .
glimmertwin14 asks : the great track black tears is a co-write with jeff beck .
can you tell us how the collaboration worked on this ( melody/chords etc ) ?
jeff does some ty great guitar throughout ( no dive bombing either ) .
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:35pm i did n't write this with jeff .
i wrote this with angelo petraglia ( he did a lot with the kings of leon , amongst others ) .
i always write alone , except for the few i did on this album which were co-written .

i had the title and idea for it already when i met angelo , and we had a great afternoon - he had this beautiful riff he was playing on the guitar and i started to sing black tears , the title , and it really flowed from there really quickly .
i 'm all about the lyrics , and he took me somewhere else i arrived at jeff 's house with the track , and he took a break from making his album loudhailer , to record this amazing solo .
my sound engineer had to run off for an emergency , and myself and the girls from bones he was recording with did the sound engineering , and the solo that jeff plays kills me every time .
it was one of the joys of my life to later get to sit and edit that solo , out of four amazing options .
lucky me .
listen to black tears , featuring jeff beck

documents.title: music should n't be the preserve of the wealthy
text: thomasrg asks : what are your views on the disproportionate amount of privately educated/funded acts in the music industry ?
is a career making music the sole reserve of the children of wealthy parents ?
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:28pm i think it 's a crying shame .
i think there are very few people from working class backgrounds in music .
i think if you really want to do it , and be in music , be involved , you 'll find a way ; i hope i 'm a good example of that .
that you do n't have to have wealth , and you do n't have to go to music college .
although i do n't know anyone who does .
i think if you have music in your bones , it does n't matter your background but it should also not discourage people from working class backgrounds .
i never felt held back i was determined to do what i loved to do .
i was addicted to it almost .
it was sheer graft , and knocking on doors , a lot of that .

i feel very strongly that funding should never be cut for the arts , as that seems to be the first thing to go in schools , and that schools are too focused on academics - they should be nurturing all kinds of children , including the creatives .
the arts should be encouraged , not cut - i feel that 's very important .
it 's almost seen as a frivolous extra , and i do n't agree .
pinkroom asks : forget about all those other chumps mentioned here ( bono , jools holland ) tell us about the great mike sanchez .
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:24pm for those who do n't know , mike sanchez is a great rhythm and blues singer , writer and piano player .
i worked with him for five years when i first came to london , and toured with him , and i learned a lot from him .
i learned stagecraft , how to connect with an audience - he taught me not to be afraid of the audience , and have fun .
the first gig we did together , i just sang to him for the whole gig and had to pretend the audience was n't there i was terrified !
he helped me move my eye contact to the audience from the band ; i learned that an audience is a group of individuals , not one scary mass .
he 's now in spain , and i got to work with him on bill wyman 's 80th birthday gig , and it was so great so see him again and work with him again .
theshiftyshadow asks : do you prefer building sandcastles or snowmen ?
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:19pm both ok , sandcastles if i have to because it means i must be by a beach preferably a warm one .
katrinelund asks : any chance of a costello-duet on your joint us-tour this summer ?
guardian contributor imelda may 24 april 2017 1:19pm i bloody hope so !
we 've already sung together , for ceiluradh , the festival in the albert hall , so i really hope we can do it again .
i sang what 's so funny bout peace love and understanding .
i 'm a big fan of his and ca n't wait for the tour .
he 's a brilliant writer .
we 're off she 's here ¦ imelda may in the guardian offices for a chat .

documents.title: post your questions for imelda may
text: alongside the rather unlikely choice of stereophonics , bob dylan recently named imelda may as one of the finest musicians working today .
and he 's not the only high-profile fan may has performed with lou reed , bono , jeff beck and tom jones among many others .
the irish singer-songwriter started out playing bars in dublin as a teenager , and began honing her twist on blues and rockabilly .
in 2008 her album love tattoo went to no 1 in ireland and broke the uk thanks in part to the patronage of jools holland .
her next two records both hit the uk top 10 .
new album life .
love .
flesh .
blood , written in the wake of a divorce , sees her take a left turn into country soul aided by producer t bone burnett .
with the album out now , she joins us to answer your questions in a live webchat from 1pm bst on monday 24 april post them in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .
